awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Everyday violence against women and the state's promotion of "universal breadwinning model"
awd_abstract_narration:
Gender equality and economic development go hand in hand. A wealth of evidence shows that economic development has a powerful, transformative, and profoundly positive effect on the social, economic and political circumstances of women. And nowhere is this relationship more apparent than in Europe where the states consistently and systematically score highly across all indicators associated with gender equality. However, despite these advances in gender equality, recent survey research shows that Europe has  high rates of violence against women, particularly by intimate partners. This project argues that this counterintuitive pattern of everyday violence against women corresponds to the implementation and promotion of specific family policies, such as paid parental leave, childcare services, and individual taxation. While these policies are designed to increase female economic independence, they also precipitate the unravelling of traditional gender roles, which then provokes a violent male backlash against their partners. By recognizing the role of the state and identifying which family policies catalyze or exacerbate everyday violence, this project will help policymakers formulate best practices for addressing violence against women and improve the status women in Europe and elsewhere.

This project examines a previously overlooked topic in political science - the issue of everyday violence against women. While analyses of conflict and the welfare state have increasingly incorporated gender and addressed issues such as wartime sexual violence and occupational sex segregation, relatively little research has been devoted to the violence against women during times of civil peace. This project investigates this unheeded phenomenon and questions why so many highly developed and egalitarian states, particularly in Europe, continue to have such high incidences of violence against women. It argues that everyday forms of violence against women are fundamentally political and can be best explained by variation in a state's implementation and promotion of the "universal breadwinning model", which undermines traditional gender norms, decreases men's intrafamily bargaining power, and then provokes a violent backlash. To test the proposed theoretical framework, this project utilizes three interconnected empirical strategies to elucidate not only the sub-national and cross-national patterns of gendered violence in Europe but also the micro-level causal mechanisms. First, the project uses an original dataset on the universal breadwinning model combined with a nationally-representative, EU-wide victimization survey to quantitatively test the association between violence and family policy in Europe. This statistical analysis is then supplemented with comparative historical analysis tracing the emergence and implementation of the universal breadwinning model, and interview research with experts and female survivors of violence, which is crucial for establishing the link between family policies and the micro-mechanism of changing intrafamily dynamics and male violence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project explores the puzzling and disturbing pattern of everyday violence against women that exists in European states. Although Europe is often regarded as a leader in women’s rights and gender equality, recent survey research has indicated that the most developed countries in Europe often have the highest rates of violence. This project argues that this counterintuitive pattern of violence is conditioned and exacerbated social welfare state policies and more specifically, family policies such as subsidized childcare and parental leave entitlements. Following other scholars, this project calls this collection of policies that “universal breadwinning model.” The common goal of the universal breadwinning model is to emancipate women from traditional gender roles.  And it does this by socializing the burdens of familyhood and household work, which in turn, encourage and allow women to participate in the formal labor force. However, the universal breadwinning model also has an unintentional and negative effect – a violent backlash from men against their female partners and spouses. Leveraging a multi-method research design that includes both quantitative and qualitative data, this project finds that there is a strong and significant relationship between certain types of family policies included under the purview of the universal breadwinning model and increased violence against women. This design, particularly the qualitative research, also allowed for greater insight into the family dynamics within abusive relationships, which supported the plausibility of male backlash.

Financial support from the National Science Foundation allowed for extensive fieldwork in the UK and Germany. This fieldwork research involved several different types of data collection. First, interviews were undertaken with female victims of everyday violence, women’s organizations, government bureaucrats, and policymakers. Second, ethnographic observation was also utilized while volunteering and participating with organizations directly supporting women, victims of domestic abuse and their communities. NSF support was also crucial in promoting professional development and allowed the investigator gain extensive experience in and knowledge about collecting interview, survey, and ethnographic data on sensitive subjects as well as the ethics of conducting such research.

Importantly, this project impacts understandings in both social science – in particular, political science – and for policymakers. First, this research demonstrates that violence against women during times of civil peace (i.e. periods without conflict) can have a political explanation. This is a critical insight because although it is the most prevalent form of violence against women, everyday violence and contributory role of the state has been largely overlooked in academic work. Second, to policymakers, this study highlights the importance of disaggregating social policies into their component parts and examining the both the intended and unintended consequences of each. This is especially essential if policymakers wish to reduce rates of everyday violence against women in broader society.
